Growth orders and ergodicity for absolutely Cesàro bounded operators

Luciano Abadias Departamento de Matemáticas, Instituto Universitario de Matemáticas y Aplicaciones, Universidad de Zaragoza, 50009 Zaragoza, Spain. labadias@unizar.es  and  Antonio Bonilla Departamento de Análisis Matemático, Universidad de la Laguna, 38271, La Laguna (Tenerife), Spain. abonilla@ull.es
Abstract.

In this paper, we extend the concept of absolutely Cesàro boundedness to the fractional case. We construct a weighted shift operator belonging to this class of operators, and we prove that if T𝑇T is an absolutely Cesàro bounded operator of order α𝛼\alpha with 0<α≤1,0𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1, then ‖Tn‖=o​(nα)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝛼\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}), generalizing the result obtained for α=1𝛼1\alpha=1. Moreover, if α>1𝛼1\alpha>1, then ‖Tn‖=O​(n)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑂𝑛\|T^{n}\|=O(n). We apply such results to get stability properties for the Cesàro means of bounded operators.

Key words and phrases:
Absolutely Cesàro bounded, Kreiss bounded, backward shift operator, ergodicity.
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
47A35, 47A10, 47B99.

1. Introduction

where (kα​(n))n∈ℕ0subscriptsuperscript𝑘𝛼𝑛𝑛subscriptℕ0(k^{\alpha}(n))_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}} is the Cesàro kernel of order α.𝛼\alpha. It is given by

where ΓΓ\Gamma is the Gamma function, and k0​(n)=δn,0superscript𝑘0𝑛subscript𝛿𝑛0k^{0}(n)=\delta_{n,0} for n∈ℕ0,𝑛subscriptℕ0n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}, where δn,jsubscript𝛿𝑛𝑗\delta_{n,j} is the Kronecker delta, i.e., δn,j=1subscript𝛿𝑛𝑗1\delta_{n,j}=1 if j=n𝑗𝑛j=n and 00 otherwise. We attach some of its properties that we will use along the paper. (1) kα​(n):=nα−1Γ​(α)​(1+O​(1/n)),assignsuperscript𝑘𝛼𝑛superscript𝑛𝛼1Γ𝛼1𝑂1𝑛k^{\alpha}(n):=\frac{n^{\alpha-1}}{\Gamma(\alpha)}(1+O(1/n)),

and kαsuperscript𝑘𝛼k^{\alpha} is increasing (as a function of n) for α>1,𝛼1\alpha>1, decreasing for 0<α<1,0𝛼10<\alpha<1, and k1​(n)=1superscript𝑘1𝑛1k^{1}(n)=1 for n∈ℕ0𝑛subscriptℕ0n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}. Moreover, the Gautschi inequality implies

For more details see [6, 16, 26].


Recall that a bounded linear operator T𝑇T on X𝑋X is called (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded if the Cesàro mean of order α𝛼\alpha of T,𝑇T, (MTα​(n))n∈ℕ0,subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛𝑛subscriptℕ0(M_{T}^{\alpha}(n))_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}}, is uniformly bounded. The particular cases α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 and α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 are well-known, the power boundedness and Cesàro boundedness respectively. It is known that (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro boundedness implies (C,β)𝐶𝛽(C,\beta)-Cesàro boundedness for β>α≥0,𝛽𝛼0\beta>\alpha\geq 0, however the converse is not true in general: the Assani matrix is Cesàro bounded but it is not power bounded. In the case that (MTα​(n))n∈ℕ0subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛𝑛subscriptℕ0(M_{T}^{\alpha}(n))_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}} converges in the strong topology of X,𝑋X, we say that the operator T𝑇T is (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-mean ergodic (for α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 it said to be mean ergodic). Properties, characterization thorough functional calculus and ergodic results for (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operators can be found in [2, 3, 7, 8, 9, 10, 15] and references therein.


Also, there are connections between some boundedness of the Cesàro means and the resolvent of T.𝑇T. We recall that the condition

‖Mλ​T2​(n)‖≤C, for ​|λ|=1​ and ​n∈ℕ0,formulae-sequencenormsubscriptsuperscript𝑀2𝜆𝑇𝑛𝐶 for 𝜆1 and 𝑛subscriptℕ0\|M^{2}_{\lambda T}(n)\|\leq C,\;\;\mbox{ for }|\lambda|=1\mbox{ and }n\in\mathbb{N}_{0},

is equivalent to the Kreiss bounded condition

‖(λ−T)−1‖≤C(|λ|−1), for all ​|λ|>1,formulae-sequencenormsuperscript𝜆𝑇1𝐶𝜆1 for all 𝜆1\|(\lambda-T)^{-1}\|\leq\frac{C}{(|\lambda|-1)},\;\;\mbox{ for all }|\lambda|>1,

and

‖Mλ​T​(n)‖≤C, for ​|λ|=1​ and ​n∈ℕ0,formulae-sequencenormsubscript𝑀𝜆𝑇𝑛𝐶 for 𝜆1 and 𝑛subscriptℕ0\|M_{\lambda T}(n)\|\leq C,\;\;\mbox{ for }|\lambda|=1\mbox{ and }n\in\mathbb{N}_{0},

is equivalent to the Uniformly Kreiss bounded condition

‖∑k=0nλ−k−1​Tk‖≤C(|λ|−1), for all ​|λ|>1,n∈ℕ0,formulae-sequencenormsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛superscript𝜆𝑘1superscript𝑇𝑘𝐶𝜆1formulae-sequence for all 𝜆1𝑛subscriptℕ0\left\|\sum_{k=0}^{n}\lambda^{-k-1}T^{k}\right\|\leq\frac{C}{(|\lambda|-1)},\;\;\mbox{ for all }|\lambda|>1,\,n\in\mathbb{N}_{0},

where C𝐶C is a positive constant. There exist Kreiss bounded operators which are not Cesàro bounded, and reciprocally, Cesàro boundedness does not imply Kreiss boundedness, see [22]. Also, there are Kreiss bounded operators that they are not uniformly Kreiss bounded, see [17]. Moreover, in finite dimensional Hilbert spaces, Kreiss bounded and power bounded are equivalent classes of operators, see [17].


Growth orders for the Cesàro means of any order (especially for the natural powers) of (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded or Kreiss bounded operators have been studied in a large amount of papers ([1, 9, 15, 19, 22] and references therein). In the following remark, we include some interesting particular cases.

Remark 1.1.

Given T∈X,𝑇𝑋T\in X, σ​(T)∩∂𝔻𝜎𝑇𝔻\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D} denotes the spectrum of T𝑇T on the unit circle and m​(σ​(T)∩∂𝔻)𝑚𝜎𝑇𝔻m(\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}) its Lebesgue measure. From [22], [19] and [5], it follows that if one of next conditions is satisfied:

  1. i)

    T𝑇T is Cesàro bounded and σ​(T)∩∂𝔻⊂{1}.𝜎𝑇𝔻1\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}\subset\{1\}.

  2. ii)

    T𝑇T is Kreiss bounded and m​(σ​(T)∩∂𝔻)=0𝑚𝜎𝑇𝔻0m(\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D})=0.

  3. iii)

    T𝑇T is uniformly Kreiss bounded and X𝑋X is a Hilbert space.

Then ‖Tn‖=o​(n)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜𝑛\|T^{n}\|=o(n).

Furthermore, a similar result to the part i) is true for α≥1,𝛼1\alpha\geq 1, that is, if T𝑇T is (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded with α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1 and σ​(T)∩∂𝔻⊂{1},𝜎𝑇𝔻1\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}\subset\{1\}, then ‖Tn‖=o​(nα)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝛼\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}) ([1, Theorem 4.3]). Also, if we only consider that T𝑇T is Cesàro bounded or Kreiss bounded, then ‖Tn‖=O​(n)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑂𝑛\|T^{n}\|=O(n) ([20, 21]).


Recently in [12], the authors introduced a new concept about the growth of the Cesàro means. An operator T∈ℬ​(X)𝑇ℬ𝑋T\in\mathcal{B}(X) is called absolutely Cesàro bounded, if there exists C>0𝐶0C>0 such that

supn∈ℕ01n+1​∑j=0n∥Tj​x∥≤C​∥x∥,x∈X.formulae-sequencesubscriptsupremum𝑛subscriptℕ01𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑛delimited-∥∥superscript𝑇𝑗𝑥𝐶delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑥𝑋\sup_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}}\frac{1}{n+1}\sum_{j=0}^{n}\lVert T^{j}x\rVert\leq C\lVert x\rVert,\quad x\in X.

The starting point of the above concept is related to the distributional chaos theory. In [5], some examples of absolutely Cesàro bounded are given, as well as its connection with power bounded and Kreiss bounded properties. Also they prove that if T𝑇T is an absolutely Cesàro bounded operator, then ‖Tn‖=o​(n).normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜𝑛\|T^{n}\|=o(n). In this paper we introduce an extension of the absolutely Cesàro boundedness, and our main aim is to construct simple examples, to study the asymptotic behaviour of the orbits, to compare with other mentioned concepts, and to show ergodic results.

Definition 1.1.

Let α>0.𝛼0\alpha>0. We say that a bounded linear operator T𝑇T on X𝑋X is absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded if there exists a constant C>0𝐶0C>0 such that

supn∈ℕ01kα+1​(n)​∑j=0nkα​(n−j)​‖Tj​x‖≤C​‖x‖,subscriptsupremum𝑛subscriptℕ01superscript𝑘𝛼1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑛superscript𝑘𝛼𝑛𝑗normsuperscript𝑇𝑗𝑥𝐶norm𝑥\sup_{n\in\mathbb{N}_{0}}\frac{1}{k^{\alpha+1}(n)}\sum_{j=0}^{n}k^{\alpha}(n-j)\|T^{j}x\|\leq C\|x\|\;,

for all x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X.

For α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, the above definition is the absolutely Cesàro boundedness. In order to clarify to the reader, we show the following sketch:

Power bounded ⇒ Absolutely ​(C,α)​-Cesàro bounded ⇒Power bounded  Absolutely 𝐶𝛼-Cesàro bounded \text{Power bounded }\Rightarrow\text{ Absolutely }(C,\alpha)\text{-Ces\`{a}ro bounded }
⇒(C,α)​-Cesàro bounded ⇒‖Tn‖=O​(nα)⇒absent𝐶𝛼-Cesàro bounded ⇒normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑂superscript𝑛𝛼\Rightarrow\ (C,\alpha)\text{-Ces\`{a}ro bounded }\Rightarrow\ \|T^{n}\|=O(n^{\alpha})

Particularly, it follows that all absolutely Cesàro bounded operators are uniformly Kreiss bounded, and that every absolutely (C,2)𝐶2(C,2)-Cesàro bounded operator is Kreiss bounded.


The outline of this paper is as follows: In Section 2, for 0<α≤1,0𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1, we construct a class of weighted backward shift operators (Tβ)β>0subscriptsubscript𝑇𝛽𝛽0(T_{\beta})_{\beta>0} on ℓp​(ℕ),superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}), for 1≤p<∞,1𝑝1\leq p<\infty, which are mixing absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded with ‖Tn‖=(n+1)βnormsuperscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑛1𝛽\|T^{n}\|=(n+1)^{\beta} for 0<β<α/p0𝛽𝛼𝑝0<\beta<\alpha/p (Theorem 2.1 and Corollary 2.1), and no (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded if β≥1/p𝛽1𝑝\beta\geq 1/p (Remark 2.1). Moreover, we prove that all absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operators in a Banach space satisfy that ‖Tn‖=o​(nα)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝛼\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}) with 0<α≤10𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1 (Corollary 2.2), generalizing the result obtained in [5] for α=1,𝛼1\alpha=1, and ‖Tn‖=O​(n)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑂𝑛\|T^{n}\|=O(n) for α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 (Corollary 2.3). In Hilbert spaces, for 0<α≤1,0𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1, if T𝑇T is an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator then ‖Tn‖=o​(nm​i​n​{α,1/2})normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝛼12\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{min\{\alpha,1/2\}}) (Corollary 2.5). In Section 3, we study some ergodic applications. We prove that the absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro boundedness in a reflexive Banach space implies (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-mean ergodicity (Corollary 3.1). Also, we study stability results for the Cesàro means of fractional order of a bounded linear operator T,𝑇T, assuming spectral and growth conditions on T𝑇T (Theorem 3.1 and Corollary 3.3).

2. Examples and growth orders of absolutely Cesàro bounded operators

We denote by {en}n∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛𝑛ℕ\{e_{n}\}_{n\in\mathbb{N}} the standard canonical basis on ℓp​(ℕ)superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) for 1≤p<∞,1𝑝1\leq p<\infty, that is, en=(δn,j)j∈ℕ:=(0,…,0,1⏟n,0,…),subscript𝑒𝑛subscriptsubscript𝛿𝑛𝑗𝑗ℕassign0…0subscript⏟1𝑛0…e_{n}=(\delta_{n,j})_{j\in\mathbb{N}}:=(0,\ldots,0,\underbrace{1}_{\begin{subarray}{c}n\end{subarray}},0,\ldots), where ℓp​(ℕ)superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) is the Lebesgue space of complex sequences x=∑j=1∞αj​ej,𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝑒𝑗x=\displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}\alpha_{j}e_{j}, with ‖x‖p:=(∑j=1∞|αj|p)1p<∞.assignsubscriptnorm𝑥𝑝superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑗𝑝1𝑝\displaystyle\|x\|_{p}:=\left(\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}\lvert\alpha_{j}\rvert^{p}\right)^{1\over p}<\infty.

In the literature, there are only simple examples of (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operators (no power bounded) for α∈ℕ.𝛼ℕ\alpha\in\mathbb{N}. In the following, we construct a class of (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded backward shift operators on ℓp​(ℕ),superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}), with 0<α<1,0𝛼10<\alpha<1, which are not power bounded.

Recall that a bounded linear operator T𝑇T on X𝑋X is topologically mixing if for any pair U,V𝑈𝑉U,V of non-empty open subsets of X𝑋X, there exists n0∈ℕsubscript𝑛0ℕn_{0}\in\mathbb{N} such that Tn​(U)∩V≠∅superscript𝑇𝑛𝑈𝑉T^{n}(U)\cap V\neq\emptyset for all n≥n0𝑛subscript𝑛0n\geq n_{0}. Therefore, we deduce the following result.

Corollary 2.1.

Let 1≤p<∞1𝑝1\leq p<\infty and 0<ε<α≤1.0𝜀𝛼10<\varepsilon<\alpha\leq 1. There exists an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator T𝑇T on ℓp​(ℕ)superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) such that it is mixing and ‖Tn‖=(n+1)(α−ε)pnormsuperscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑛1𝛼𝜀𝑝\|T^{n}\|=(n+1)^{\frac{(\alpha-\varepsilon)}{p}}.

Proof.

By Theorem 2.1 we have that the unilateral weighted backward shift operator on ℓp​(ℕ)superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) is absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded and

(6) ‖Tn‖=(n+1)(α−ε)p.normsuperscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑛1𝛼𝜀𝑝\|T^{n}\|=(n+1)^{\frac{(\alpha-\varepsilon)}{p}}\;.

Moreover, by [11, Theorem 4.8] we have that T𝑇T is mixing since (∏k=1nwk)−1→0→superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑘10\left(\prod_{k=1}^{n}w_{k}\right)^{-1}\to 0 as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty. ∎

The unilateral weighted backward shift operator on ℓp​(ℕ),superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}), with β=1p,𝛽1𝑝\beta=\frac{1}{p}, given in Theorem 2.1, is not Cesàro bounded, and so it is not (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded for 0<α<1,0𝛼10<\alpha<1, see [5]. It is natural to ask if this operator is (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded for some α>1.𝛼1\alpha>1. The answer is negative as the following proposition shows.

Proposition 2.1.

The unilateral weighted backward shift operator T𝑇T on ℓp​(ℕ)superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) with 1≤p<∞,1𝑝1\leq p<\infty, given by T​e1:=0assign𝑇subscript𝑒10Te_{1}:=0 and T​ej:=wj​ej−1assign𝑇subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑤𝑗subscript𝑒𝑗1Te_{j}:=w_{j}e_{j-1} for j>1,𝑗1j>1, with wj:=(jj−1)1/p,assignsubscript𝑤𝑗superscript𝑗𝑗11𝑝w_{j}:=\displaystyle\left(\frac{j}{j-1}\right)^{1/p}, is not (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded for any α𝛼\alpha.

with C𝐶C a positive constant, where we have used that kαsuperscript𝑘𝛼k^{\alpha} is increasing as function of n𝑛n for α>1,𝛼1\alpha>1, identity (1) and kα∗k1=kα+1superscript𝑘𝛼superscript𝑘1superscript𝑘𝛼1k^{\alpha}*k^{1}=k^{\alpha+1}. So, we conclude that the Cesàro mean of order α𝛼\alpha of T𝑇T is not uniformly bounded. ∎

Remark 2.1.

Let 0<α≤10𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1, 1≤p<∞,1𝑝1\leq p<\infty, β>0𝛽0\beta>0 and T𝑇T be the unilateral weighted backward shift operator on ℓp​(ℕ)superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) defined in Theorem 2.1. Then the operator T𝑇T is absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded if β<α/p𝛽𝛼𝑝\beta<\alpha/p (Theorem 2.1) and no (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded if β≥1/p𝛽1𝑝\beta\geq 1/p (Proposition 2.1).

From now to the end of the section we focus on studying the growth of the natural powers of absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operators.

Theorem 2.2.

Let 0<α≤1,0𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1, X𝑋X be a Banach space and T∈B​(X)𝑇𝐵𝑋T\in B(X) satisfying ‖Tn‖=O​(nα).normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑂superscript𝑛𝛼\|T^{n}\|=O(n^{\alpha}). Then either ‖Tn‖=o​(nα)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝛼\displaystyle\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}) or the set

{x∈X:supN1kα+1​(N)​∑j=0Nkα​(N−j)​‖Tj​x‖=∞}conditional-set𝑥𝑋subscriptsupremum𝑁1superscript𝑘𝛼1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑁superscript𝑘𝛼𝑁𝑗normsuperscript𝑇𝑗𝑥\Bigl{\{}x\in X:\sup_{N}\frac{1}{k^{\alpha+1}(N)}\sum_{j=0}^{N}k^{\alpha}(N-j)\|T^{j}x\|=\infty\Bigr{\}}

is residual in X𝑋X.

Proof.

Suppose that ‖Tn‖nα↛0↛normsuperscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑛𝛼0\frac{\|T^{n}\|}{n^{\alpha}}\not\to 0 as n→∞.→𝑛n\to\infty. So, there exists a positive constant c𝑐c such that

Also, by hypothesis, there is C>0𝐶0C>0 such that ‖Tn‖≤C​nαnormsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝐶superscript𝑛𝛼\|T^{n}\|\leq Cn^{\alpha} for all n∈ℕ.𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}.

For s∈ℕ𝑠ℕs\in\mathbb{N} we denote

Ms={x∈X:supN1kα+1​(N)​∑j=0Nkα​(N−j)​‖Tj​x‖>s}.subscript𝑀𝑠conditional-set𝑥𝑋subscriptsupremum𝑁1superscript𝑘𝛼1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑁superscript𝑘𝛼𝑁𝑗normsuperscript𝑇𝑗𝑥𝑠M_{s}=\Bigl{\{}x\in X:\sup_{N}\frac{1}{k^{\alpha+1}(N)}\sum_{j=0}^{N}k^{\alpha}(N-j)\|T^{j}x\|>s\Bigr{\}}.

It is clear that Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s} is an open set.

First, we show that Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s} contains a unit vector for s∈ℕ𝑠ℕs\in\mathbb{N}. and so x∈Ms𝑥subscript𝑀𝑠x\in M_{s}.

Hence either y+ε​x∈Ms𝑦𝜀𝑥subscript𝑀𝑠y+\varepsilon x\in M_{s} or y−ε​x∈Ms𝑦𝜀𝑥subscript𝑀𝑠y-\varepsilon x\in M_{s}. Since ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 was arbitrary, we conclude that Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s} is dense.

The Baire category theorem implies that

⋂s+1∞Ms={x∈X:supN1kα+1​(N)​∑j=0Nkα​(N−j)​‖Tj​x‖=∞}superscriptsubscript𝑠1subscript𝑀𝑠conditional-set𝑥𝑋subscriptsupremum𝑁1superscript𝑘𝛼1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑁superscript𝑘𝛼𝑁𝑗normsuperscript𝑇𝑗𝑥\bigcap_{s+1}^{\infty}M_{s}=\Bigl{\{}x\in X:\sup_{N}\frac{1}{k^{\alpha+1}(N)}\sum_{j=0}^{N}k^{\alpha}(N-j)\|T^{j}x\|=\infty\Bigr{\}}

is a residual set. ∎

Corollary 2.2.

Let 0<α≤10𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1 and T𝑇T be an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator. Then ‖Tn‖=o​(nα)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝛼\displaystyle\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}).

Proof.

Note that by the absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro boundedness of T,𝑇T, we have

‖Tn​x‖≤∑j=0nkα​(n−j)​‖Tj​x‖≤C​kα+1​(n)​‖x‖≤C​nα​‖x‖,C>0.formulae-sequencenormsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑛superscript𝑘𝛼𝑛𝑗normsuperscript𝑇𝑗𝑥𝐶superscript𝑘𝛼1𝑛norm𝑥𝐶superscript𝑛𝛼norm𝑥𝐶0\|T^{n}x\|\leq\sum_{j=0}^{n}k^{\alpha}(n-j)\|T^{j}x\|\leq Ck^{\alpha+1}(n)\|x\|\leq Cn^{\alpha}\|x\|,\quad C>0.

By Theorem 2.2, we conclude the result, since the second possibility in Theorem 2.2 contradicts the absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro boundedness of T.𝑇T. ∎

Theorem 2.3.

Let T𝑇T be an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator with α>1𝛼1\alpha>1. Then T𝑇T is Kreiss bounded.

Proof.

For each β>α𝛽𝛼\beta>\alpha the operator T𝑇T is an absolutely (C,β)𝐶𝛽(C,\beta)-Cesàro bounded operator. Then, by [23, Corollary 2.3] we get the result.

∎

The following corollary is a straightforward consequence of Theorem 2.3 and [21, p.344] (or [20, Proposition 2]).

Corollary 2.3.

Let T𝑇T be an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator with α>1𝛼1\alpha>1. Then ‖Tn‖=O​(n)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑂𝑛\|T^{n}\|=O(n)

Also, by Theorem 2.1 we have the next result.

Corollary 2.4.

Let T𝑇T be an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator with α>1𝛼1\alpha>1. Then ‖Tn‖=o​(n)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜𝑛\|T^{n}\|=o(n) or T𝑇T is not absolutely Cesàro bounded.

Remark 2.2.

For any 0<β<1,0𝛽10<\beta<1, there exists an operator on ℓ1​(ℕ)superscriptℓ1ℕ\ell^{1}(\mathbb{N}) which is absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded for α>β𝛼𝛽\alpha>\beta (Theorem 2.1) and no absolutely (C,γ)𝐶𝛾(C,\gamma)-Cesàro bounded for 0<γ≤β0𝛾𝛽0<\gamma\leq\beta (Corollary 2.1, Corollary 2.2). It would be interesting to find an example of an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator with α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 such that it is not absolutely Cesàro bounded.


In Hilbert spaces, it is known that if there exists ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 such that T∈ℬ​(X)𝑇ℬ𝑋T\in\mathcal{B}(X) satisfies ‖Tn‖≥C​n12+εnormsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝐶superscript𝑛12𝜀\|T^{n}\|\geq Cn^{\frac{1}{2}+\varepsilon} for all n𝑛n, then there exists x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X such that ‖Tn​x‖→∞→normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑥\|T^{n}x\|\rightarrow\infty, see by [18, Theorem 3]. Therefore T𝑇T is not absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded for any α>0𝛼0\alpha>0.

As consequence of Corollary 2.2 and [5, Theorem 2.4], we have

Corollary 2.5.

Let H𝐻H be a Hilbert space and T𝑇T be an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator with 0<α≤10𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1. Then limn→∞‖Tn‖nm​i​n​{α,1/2}=0subscript→𝑛normsuperscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛𝛼120\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\displaystyle\frac{\|T^{n}\|}{n^{min\{\alpha,1/2\}}}=0

3. Ergodic applications for the Cesàro means

In this section we study the ergodic behaviour of the Cesàro means supposing several assumptions, both the geometry of the Banach space X𝑋X, and spectral and growth conditions on the operator T.𝑇T.

In the first results, the reflexive property plays role. As consequence of Corollary 2.2, Corollary 2.3 and [10, Proposition 3.2], we obtain the following result.

Corollary 3.1.

Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. Every absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator in a reflexive Banach space is (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-mean ergodic.

Hence, by Corollary 2.1, we have the next corollary.

Corollary 3.2.

Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. There exists a mixing (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-mean ergodic operator on ℓp​(ℕ)superscriptℓ𝑝ℕ\ell^{p}(\mathbb{N}) for 1<p<∞1𝑝1<p<\infty.

Results according to previous ones are shown in [3, 4, 5] for α=1.𝛼1\alpha=1.


From now on, we focus on stability results for the Cesàro mean differences of size n𝑛n and n+1𝑛1n+1 for bounded operators. In 1986, Y. Katznelson and L. Tzafriri proved that if T∈ℬ​(X)𝑇ℬ𝑋T\in\mathcal{B}(X) is power bounded, then limn→∞∥Tn−Tn+1∥=0subscript→𝑛delimited-∥∥superscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑇𝑛10\lim_{n\to\infty}\lVert T^{n}-T^{n+1}\rVert=0 if and only if σ​(T)∩∂𝔻⊂{1},𝜎𝑇𝔻1\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}\subset\{1\}, see [13, Theorem 1]. If T𝑇T is (C,1)𝐶1(C,1)-Cesàro bounded and σ​(T)∩∂𝔻={1},𝜎𝑇𝔻1\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}=\{1\}, but T𝑇T is not power bounded, then ∥Tn−Tn+1∥delimited-∥∥superscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑇𝑛1\lVert T^{n}-T^{n+1}\rVert need not converge to zero. See examples in [14, 24]. Also, the result is not true if the condition (C,1)𝐶1(C,1)-Cesàro bounded is changed by Kreiss bounded, see [19, Example 4]. Recently, in [1], the author proved that if T𝑇T is (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded, with α>0,𝛼0\alpha>0, and σ​(T)∩∂𝔻⊂{1},𝜎𝑇𝔻1\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}\subset\{1\}, then limn→∞∥MTα​(n+1)−MTα​(n)∥=0.subscript→𝑛delimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛0\lim_{n\to\infty}\lVert M_{T}^{\alpha}(n+1)-M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)\rVert=0.

We recall the following lemma which will be used in the proof of the main theorem of this section.

Lemma 3.1.

([25, Lemma 1]) Let α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 and T∈ℬ​(X)𝑇ℬ𝑋T\in\mathcal{B}(X) such that ‖Tn‖=o​(nω)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝜔\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\omega}), where w=m​i​n​(1,α).𝑤𝑚𝑖𝑛1𝛼w=min(1,\alpha). Then limn→∞‖MTα​(n)​(T−I)‖=0subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛𝑇𝐼0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)(T-I)\|=0.

Theorem 3.1.

If any of the following conditions is true:

  1. a)

    T𝑇T is an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator and 0<α≤1,0𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1,

  2. b)

    T𝑇T is Kreiss bounded, 1≤α<21𝛼21\leq\alpha<2 and m​(σ​(T)∩∂𝔻)=0𝑚𝜎𝑇𝔻0m(\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D})=0,

  3. c)

    T𝑇T is Kreiss bounded and α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2,

then

limn→∞‖MTα​(n+1)−MTα​(n)‖=0.subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n+1)-M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)\|=0.
Proof.

a) If α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, from the known identity

n+2n+1​MT​(n+1)−MT​(n)=1n+1​Tn+1,𝑛2𝑛1subscript𝑀𝑇𝑛1subscript𝑀𝑇𝑛1𝑛1superscript𝑇𝑛1\frac{n+2}{n+1}M_{T}(n+1)-M_{T}(n)=\frac{1}{n+1}T^{n+1},

one gets

MT​(n+1)−MT​(n)=1n+1​Tn+1−1n+1​MT​(n+1).subscript𝑀𝑇𝑛1subscript𝑀𝑇𝑛1𝑛1superscript𝑇𝑛11𝑛1subscript𝑀𝑇𝑛1M_{T}(n+1)-M_{T}(n)=\frac{1}{n+1}T^{n+1}-\frac{1}{n+1}M_{T}(n+1).

If 0<α<10𝛼10<\alpha<1, note that

see [1, p.79]. By Corollary 2.2 and Lemma 3.1 we have

limn→∞‖MTα​(n)​(T−I)‖=0,subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛𝑇𝐼0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)(T-I)\|=0,

and therefore limn→∞‖MTα​(n+1)−MTα​(n)‖=0.subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n+1)-M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)\|=0.

b) Note that by Remark 1.1 ii) we have that ‖Tn‖=o​(n)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜𝑛\|T^{n}\|=o(n). Then by Lemma 3.1, one gets limn→∞‖MTα​(n)​(T−I)‖=0subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛𝑇𝐼0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)(T-I)\|=0 for 1≤α<2.1𝛼21\leq\alpha<2. Using that the Kreiss condition implies ∥MT​(n)∥=O​(ln⁡(n))delimited-∥∥subscript𝑀𝑇𝑛𝑂𝑛\lVert M_{T}(n)\rVert=O(\ln(n)) ([21, Theorem 6.2]), we have that limn→∞‖1n​MTα​(n)‖≤limn→∞1n​sup0≤j≤n‖MT​(j)‖=0subscript→𝑛norm1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛subscript→𝑛1𝑛subscriptsupremum0𝑗𝑛normsubscript𝑀𝑇𝑗0\lim_{n\to\infty}\|\frac{1}{n}M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)\|\leq\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\sup_{0\leq j\leq n}\|M_{T}(j)\|=0. By the above comments and the following identity ([1, p.78])

we conclude the result.

c) By [21, Theorem 6.2], since α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2 we have

limn→∞‖1n​MTα−1​(n)‖≤limn→∞1n​sup0≤j≤n‖MT​(n)‖=0.subscript→𝑛norm1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼1𝑛subscript→𝑛1𝑛subscriptsupremum0𝑗𝑛normsubscript𝑀𝑇𝑛0\lim_{n\to\infty}\|\frac{1}{n}M_{T}^{\alpha-1}(n)\|\leq\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\sup_{0\leq j\leq n}\|M_{T}(n)\|=0.

Doing use of the identity ([1, p.78])

limn→∞‖MTα​(n+1)−MTα​(n)‖=0.subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n+1)-M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)\|=0.

∎

Since all absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operators are Kreiss bounded, we get the following corollary.

Corollary 3.3.

Let T𝑇T be an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator. If any of the following conditions is true:

  1. a)

    1<α<21𝛼21<\alpha<2 and m​(σ​(T)∩∂𝔻)=0𝑚𝜎𝑇𝔻0m(\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D})=0,

  2. b)

    α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2,

then

limn→∞‖MTα​(n+1)−MTα​(n)‖=0.subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛0\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n+1)-M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)\|=0.

We deduce from Theorem 3.1 a) that if 0<α≤10𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1 and T𝑇T is an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator, then ‖MTα​(n)​(T−I)‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛𝑇𝐼\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)(T-I)\| converges to zero as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty. So, a natural question is if the following extended version of the Katznelson-Tzafriri theorem is true:

Question 3.1.

Is there α𝛼\alpha with 0<α≤10𝛼10<\alpha\leq 1 such that if T𝑇T is an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator with σ​(T)∩∂𝔻={1},𝜎𝑇𝔻1\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}=\{1\}, ‖Tn​(T−I)‖normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑇𝐼\|T^{n}(T-I)\| converges to zero as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty?

On the other hand, assuming a less restrictive condition (1<α<21𝛼21<\alpha<2), we obtain the next ergodic result.

Theorem 3.2.

Let T𝑇T be an absolutely (C,α)𝐶𝛼(C,\alpha)-Cesàro bounded operator with 1<α<21𝛼21<\alpha<2. Then limn→∞‖MTα​(n)​(T−I)2‖=0.subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛superscript𝑇𝐼20\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)(T-I)^{2}\|=0.

Proof.

If 1<α<21𝛼21<\alpha<2, we have by Corollary 2.3 that ‖Tn‖=o​(nα)normsuperscript𝑇𝑛𝑜superscript𝑛𝛼\|T^{n}\|=o(n^{\alpha}), then following the ideas in [9, p.9 and 10] one gets

limn→∞‖MTα​(n)​(T−I)2‖=0.subscript→𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝑀𝑇𝛼𝑛superscript𝑇𝐼20\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{T}^{\alpha}(n)(T-I)^{2}\|=0.

∎

To finish, we comment the relevance of the conditions for Theorem 3.1 in the Kreiss bounded case.

Remark 3.1.

The condition m​(σ​(T)∩∂𝔻)=0𝑚𝜎𝑇𝔻0m(\sigma(T)\cap\partial\mathbb{D})=0 in Theorem 3.1 b) is not redundant. Indeed, in the proof of [19, Theorem 6], the author constructs a bounded linear operator A𝐴A on a Banach space of analytic functions in the unit disc such that A𝐴A is Kreiss bounded and σ​(A)∩∂𝔻𝜎𝐴𝔻\sigma(A)\cap\partial\mathbb{D} has positive measure. Moreover, it satisfies that

(7) ‖An‖≥1+n2​m​(σ​(A)∩∂𝔻).normsuperscript𝐴𝑛1𝑛2𝑚𝜎𝐴𝔻\|A^{n}\|\geq 1+\frac{n}{2}m(\sigma(A)\cap\partial\mathbb{D}).

Then the identity

MA​(n+1)−MA​(n)=1n+1​An+1−1n+1​MA​(n+1),subscript𝑀𝐴𝑛1subscript𝑀𝐴𝑛1𝑛1superscript𝐴𝑛11𝑛1subscript𝑀𝐴𝑛1M_{A}(n+1)-M_{A}(n)=\frac{1}{n+1}A^{n+1}-\frac{1}{n+1}M_{A}(n+1),

identity (7) and [21, Theorem 6.2] imply

limn→∞‖MA​(n+1)−MA​(n)‖≠0.subscript→𝑛normsubscript𝑀𝐴𝑛1subscript𝑀𝐴𝑛0\lim_{n\to\infty}\|M_{A}(n+1)-M_{A}(n)\|\neq 0.
